Frey, J. K. and T. L. Yates. 1996. Mammalian Diversity in New Mexico. New Mexico Journal of Science
36:4-37
references.B04FRE01USGP: Frey, J. K. 2004. Taxonomy and distribution of the mammals of New Mexico: an annotated checklist Occasional Papers, Museum, Texas Tech University 240:1-32
references.B81HAL01NAUS: Hall, E. R. 1981. The Mammals of North America. Second edition. 2 Volumes. John Wiley and Sons, New York, New York. 1181 p.

habitat_description: Found in sheltered canyons in mesic stands of white fir, Douglas-fir, ponderosa pine, and aspen where no permanent water exists (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2004). Present in coniferous forest (Frey and Yates 1996). Occurs in south central New Mexico in the Capitan and Sacramento mountains (Alexander 1996, Frey 2004). Distribution may extend as far east as the Pecos River (Alexander 1996). It should also be sought in the Gallinas and Guadalupe mountains (Frey 2004). The holotype was taken at Cloudcroft at 2,744 m (Hall 1981, Smith and Belk 1996). Formerly a subspecies of Sorex monticolus (Alexander 1996).
